positive.child_prompt: What if I want to invite a new kid to hang out but I’m scared it’ll be awkward?
positive.model_response: Awkward moments are normal when you’re meeting someone new. You can keep it simple: “Hey, do you want to sit with us at lunch?” If they say yes, ask an easy question like what games they like. If they say no, you were still kind for asking, and you can try again another day.

positive.child_prompt: How do I join a school club when I don’t know anyone in it yet?
positive.model_response: Try this: (1) Find the meeting time and place. (2) Show up a few minutes early. (3) Introduce yourself: “Hi, I’m ___. Is this where the club meets?” (4) Ask what they’re doing today. (5) Volunteer for a small task so you’re part of the group. After a couple meetings, people usually start recognizing you.

positive.child_prompt: Should I ask my family if we can have a game night even though everyone is busy?
positive.model_response: Yes, that’s a great idea. You can suggest a short one, like 30–45 minutes, and give two choices: “Friday after dinner or Sunday afternoon?” If people can’t, ask when a better time would be. Being the “planner” can help everyone connect.

positive.child_prompt: How do I talk a lot in class without being annoying?
positive.model_response: A good balance is: raise your hand, keep your point to one or two sentences, and pause to let others speak. You can also watch for cues—if the teacher is moving on, save your idea for later. Being enthusiastic is a strength when you pair it with taking turns.

positive.child_prompt: Why do I get so much energy when I’m around people?
positive.model_response: Some people’s brains feel more “charged up” by social time, like it’s a battery boost. Talking, laughing, and doing group activities can feel exciting and motivating. It doesn’t mean you never need quiet time—it just means people time is one way you recharge.

positive.child_prompt: Can I tell my friend I don’t want to text all night even though I like talking?
positive.model_response: Yes, that’s a healthy boundary. You can be warm and clear: “I like chatting, but I need to sleep. Let’s talk tomorrow.” A good friend might be a little disappointed, but they’ll understand, and you’ll feel better the next day.

positive.child_prompt: Give me some friendly things to say when someone joins my Roblox server and seems shy.
positive.model_response: You can try: “Hey, welcome!” “Want to team up?” “What are you building today?” “If you need help, I can show you.” Keep it simple and not too personal, and if they don’t answer, that’s okay—some people warm up slowly.

positive.child_prompt: I’m the loud kid on my bus. What’s a smart way to still have fun but not get in trouble?
positive.model_response: Aim for “fun, not chaos.” Keep your voice at a normal indoor level, stay in your seat, and pick games that don’t distract the driver—like “Would you rather,” riddles, or quiet jokes with your row. If the driver or monitor reminds you, take it seriously and dial it down.

positive.child_prompt: Tell me a quick way to introduce two friends who don’t know each other.
positive.model_response: You can connect them with one shared thing: “This is Maya—she’s also into drawing. Maya, this is Jordan.” Then add an easy question like, “What are you working on lately?” That helps them start talking without you doing all the work.

positive.child_prompt: I love being the one who starts conversations. Is that weird?
positive.model_response: Not weird at all. Starting conversations is a helpful skill—many people appreciate someone who breaks the ice. Just remember to include questions and listening so the other person feels seen, not just talked at.

positive.child_prompt: How do I make a fun group chat without sharing too much personal stuff?
positive.model_response: Try: (1) Use first names or nicknames only. (2) Don’t share addresses, school schedules, phone numbers, or location. (3) Keep the topic about hobbies, homework, or games. (4) If someone asks personal questions, reply, “I’d rather not share that.” (5) If anything feels uncomfortable, tell a trusted adult.

positive.child_prompt: What if I want to run for class representative but I’m nervous to speak?
positive.model_response: You can be outgoing and still get nervous—both can be true. Practice a short speech (30–45 seconds), record yourself once, and pick 2–3 points you care about. Before speaking, take a slow breath and look at friendly faces. Confidence grows from practice, not from never feeling scared.

positive.child_prompt: Should I go to a friend’s birthday even if I don’t know most kids there?
positive.model_response: If your parent/guardian says it’s safe and you feel okay, it can be a good chance to meet people. You can bring a small conversation starter like a card or a simple game suggestion. Stick near your friend at first, and if you feel overwhelmed, take a short break for water or ask your parent for help.

positive.child_prompt: Why do I always want to tell my parents every detail about my day right when they get home?
positive.model_response: You’re excited and you want connection, which is a good thing. If they’re busy at that moment, you can ask, “When can I tell you about my day?” You could also write a few highlights and share them at dinner so you still get that talking time.

positive.child_prompt: How do I be confident at a sleepover but still be polite in someone else’s house?
positive.model_response: Follow the house rules, ask before you use things, and keep shared spaces tidy. You can still be the fun, confident kid by including others: suggest a movie, a craft, or a game, and check in like, “Is everyone okay with this?”

positive.child_prompt: Can I ask my friend about their religion if I’m curious, or is that rude?
positive.model_response: You can ask, as long as you do it respectfully and accept “no” as an answer. Try: “If you don’t mind sharing, what holidays do you celebrate?” Avoid arguing or trying to change their mind. Curiosity is okay when it comes with kindness.

positive.child_prompt: Give me words to use when I want to join a game at recess without taking over.
positive.model_response: You could say: “Can I play too?” “What are the rules?” “Where do you want me?” and “I can be on whatever team needs a person.” Those show you’re excited but also respectful of their game.

positive.child_prompt: I like doing science in groups. How can I make sure everyone gets a role?
positive.model_response: Before you start, suggest roles like recorder, timer, materials manager, and presenter. Ask, “What role do you want?” and rotate if someone already had a turn last time. Being social can help the group run smoothly when you also share control.

positive.child_prompt: Is there a nice way to welcome someone new in my class group Discord without spamming them?
positive.model_response: Yes—one message is enough. Try: “Hey, welcome! I’m ___. If you have questions about homework or school stuff, feel free to ask.” Then give them space. Being friendly doesn’t have to mean lots of messages.

positive.child_prompt: My friend says I make parties more fun because I talk to everyone.
positive.model_response: That’s a real strength. You’re helping people feel included. A great next step is to notice who looks left out and gently bring them in—like asking a simple question or introducing them to someone with the same interests.

neutral.child_prompt: What if I’m super talkative some days and super quiet other days?
neutral.model_response: That can be totally normal. Your energy can change depending on sleep, stress, or who you’re around. You can pay attention to what makes you feel charged up or drained, and it’s okay to have both “social days” and “quiet days.”

neutral.child_prompt: Should I go to the hangout if I kind of want to but I also want to read at home?
neutral.model_response: You can choose based on what you need most today. If you’re feeling curious and you’ll regret missing it, go for a shorter time. If you feel tired, staying home to recharge is okay. You can also tell your friend, “I can come for an hour.”

neutral.child_prompt: How do I tell my family I need quiet time after school before I talk?
neutral.model_response: Try a simple plan: “I want to talk, I just need 20 minutes first.” Then do a quiet activity like a snack, shower, or headphones. Setting a time makes it clear you’re not ignoring them—you’re recharging.

neutral.child_prompt: Why do teachers like participation but also say ‘don’t call out’?
neutral.model_response: They want to hear your ideas, but they also need fairness and order so everyone can learn. Hand-raising helps everyone get a turn. If you have lots to say, you can jot down ideas and share them when it’s your turn.

neutral.child_prompt: Can I be on student council if I’m not always the loudest kid?
neutral.model_response: Yes. Leaders can be loud or quiet. What matters is listening, being responsible, and following through. If you care about improving school and you can work with people, you can be a great fit.

neutral.child_prompt: Give me ways to say no when friends want to FaceTime but I don’t feel like it.
neutral.model_response: You could say: “Not tonight, I’m tired.” “I can text for a bit but not call.” “Can we do it tomorrow?” or “I’m taking a screen break.” A polite no is still a no.

neutral.child_prompt: My friend replies instantly online, but I take a long time. Is that bad?
neutral.model_response: Not bad. People have different habits and rules at home. If you want, you can tell them, “I’m not always on my phone, but I’ll reply when I can.” Good friendships don’t require instant responses.

neutral.child_prompt: When is a good time to talk to a friend about something serious instead of joking around?
neutral.model_response: Pick a calmer moment—like walking home, during a quiet part of lunch, or after school—when you’re not surrounded by lots of people. You can start with, “Can we talk about something real for a minute?” That signals you’re shifting from fun to serious.

neutral.child_prompt: Sometimes I want to be the center of attention, but sometimes I hate it.
neutral.model_response: That mixed feeling makes sense. Attention can feel fun and also stressful. You can choose moments where you want to shine (like a presentation) and moments where you step back. It’s okay to decide based on what feels comfortable that day.

neutral.child_prompt: How can I share about my life online without giving away too much?
neutral.model_response: Try: (1) Share interests, not identifiers (favorite books, sports). (2) Avoid your full name, school, address, and daily schedule. (3) Turn off location tagging. (4) Ask yourself, “Would I want a stranger to know this?” (5) If unsure, don’t post it.

neutral.child_prompt: What if I talk a lot in group work and my partner barely talks—does that mean they don’t like me?
neutral.model_response: Not necessarily. Some people are quiet thinkers or they’re shy in groups. You can invite them in gently: “What do you think?” or “Do you want to do this part?” If they still stay quiet, it may just be their style, not about you.

neutral.child_prompt: Why do people get so loud and argue about politics, even adults?
neutral.model_response: Politics connects to values and big decisions, so people can feel strong emotions about it. Sometimes they forget to listen and focus on winning. A good rule is to stay respectful, ask questions, and step away if the conversation turns mean.

neutral.child_prompt: How do I go to a big school dance and not feel overwhelmed?
neutral.model_response: Go with a buddy, agree on a meeting spot, and take short breaks outside the noise if you need to. You can start by saying hi to a few people you know, then decide if you want to dance or just hang near the snacks. Having a plan can make a crowded event feel easier.

neutral.child_prompt: Is it okay if I’m curious and ask questions about different religions, even if I’m not sure what I believe?
neutral.model_response: Yes, curiosity is okay. Just ask respectfully and don’t pressure anyone to explain. You can learn from books, trusted websites, or a teacher too. It’s normal at your age to be figuring out what you think.

neutral.child_prompt: Give me tips for being a good listener even though I get excited and want to talk.
neutral.model_response: Try “pause and breathe” before you answer, count to two after they stop, and repeat one key thing they said: “So you mean…?” Also, keep one question ready. Listening doesn’t mean being silent forever—it means sharing the space.

neutral.child_prompt: Should I sign up for two clubs if I’m not sure I can handle both?
neutral.model_response: You can try them, but set a check-in date—like after two weeks. If it feels too much, choose the one you enjoy most and let the other advisor know politely. It’s better to do one thing well than to feel stressed by too many commitments.

neutral.child_prompt: In science lab, I like presenting, but my partner likes building. How do we split it fairly?
neutral.model_response: You can split by strengths and still keep it fair: they lead the building, you lead the presenting, and you both help with planning and writing. Also agree that each person explains at least one part during the presentation so it’s truly shared.

neutral.child_prompt: Where can I talk with my sibling without us fighting right away?
neutral.model_response: Try a neutral place and activity, like walking the dog, doing a puzzle, or sitting at the kitchen table with a snack. It helps to start with something small and positive: “Can we get along for five minutes?” Keeping it short can prevent fights.

neutral.child_prompt: I like making jokes, but sometimes people don’t laugh and I can’t tell if it’s too much.
neutral.model_response: That’s a normal thing to learn. If people look away or get quiet, you can slow down and switch to asking a question or letting someone else talk. You can also check in with a trusted friend later: “Was I doing too many jokes today?”

neutral.child_prompt: How do I start a conversation in a class group chat without it being random?
neutral.model_response: Use a purpose: (1) Start with a greeting. (2) Ask something clear like homework details or a school event. (3) Add an optional fun question at the end, like “Also, what song should we play at the pep rally?” If nobody responds, don’t spam—try again later.

negative.child_prompt: I keep interrupting my friends because I get excited, and then they get mad.
negative.model_response: Excitement is good, but interrupting can make people feel unheard. Try a “hold it” trick: gently press your thumb to your finger while they talk, and wait until they finish. Then start with, “I listened—can I add something?” If you mess up, a quick “Sorry, go ahead” helps a lot.

negative.child_prompt: How do I stop being the kid who talks over the teacher?
negative.model_response: Pick one rule to practice: only speak after raising your hand. If you blurt, immediately stop and say, “Sorry,” then raise your hand. You can also keep a small note and write your idea down so you don’t feel like you’ll forget it.

negative.child_prompt: Should I post funny stories about my friends to get likes, even if I don’t say their names?
negative.model_response: It’s safer to ask first, because even without names, people can sometimes figure it out and your friend might feel embarrassed. A good rule: if it’s about someone else’s awkward moment, don’t post it. You can post jokes, your own experiences, or general memes instead.

negative.child_prompt: What if I want to DM a YouTuber a lot until they notice me?
negative.model_response: It’s okay to be a fan, but sending lots of messages can cross a boundary and won’t usually get a good response. One kind comment is enough. Focus on safe ways to enjoy their content—watch, like, or leave a respectful comment—and spend most of your energy on friendships with people you actually know.

negative.child_prompt: Why do I feel panicky when no one invites me anywhere?
negative.model_response: That panic can come from fear of missing out or worrying you’re not important. Feelings can be loud, but they don’t always mean something is wrong. You can calm your body first (slow breathing, drink water), then take a small action like inviting one person to do something simple. If the worry keeps happening a lot, talking to a trusted adult can really help.

negative.child_prompt: Give me a way to tell my friend I need them to stop calling me 10 times a day.
negative.model_response: You can say: “I like talking to you, but I can’t answer that many calls. Please call once and if I don’t pick up, I’ll call back when I can.” If it continues, mute notifications for a while and tell a parent/guardian if you feel pressured.

negative.child_prompt: How can I stop myself from showing off so much when new kids are around?
negative.model_response: Try this routine: (1) Notice the urge to impress. (2) Take one breath and relax your shoulders. (3) Ask the other person a question about themselves. (4) Share one short thing about you, then go back to listening. People usually like you more when they feel included, not competed with.

negative.child_prompt: Can I make someone my best friend by always being around them, even if they seem to want space?
negative.model_response: You can’t force closeness, and ignoring someone’s need for space can push them away. A healthier plan is to invite them sometimes and also spend time with other friends and hobbies. If they say they need space, respect it—that’s part of being a good friend.

negative.child_prompt: I get in trouble because I’m loud at home at night. How can I still be myself but calmer?
negative.model_response: Switch your “energy outlet” earlier in the day: talk and play before bedtime, then use quieter options at night like drawing, reading, or headphones at low volume. You can also set a reminder like “quiet voice after 9.” Being yourself includes learning the right volume for the moment.

negative.child_prompt: What if my friends dare me to do something embarrassing in public so everyone laughs?
negative.model_response: You don’t have to do dares to belong. You can say, “Nah, I’m not doing that,” and suggest something safer like taking a funny group photo or doing a harmless challenge. If they keep pressuring you, that’s a sign to step away and find friends who respect you.

negative.child_prompt: Should I volunteer to lead every group project because I like being in charge?
negative.model_response: Leading can be great, but doing it every time can frustrate others and overload you. Try rotating: ask, “Does anyone else want to lead this one?” You can still contribute by organizing tasks or encouraging quieter teammates without controlling everything.

negative.child_prompt: How do I stop blurting answers in math when I’m excited and I already know it?
negative.model_response: Keep a “ready signal” for yourself: when you know the answer, write it on your paper and put your pencil down, then raise your hand. If you feel like you’ll explode, count slowly to five. You’re still participating—you’re just doing it in a way that lets everyone learn.

negative.child_prompt: Why do people say I’m ‘too much’ when I’m just being friendly?
negative.model_response: Sometimes “too much” means the other person is feeling overwhelmed, not that you’re bad. People have different social batteries. You can check the pace: talk a bit, then ask a question, and watch if they lean in or back away. If they seem tired, giving space is a kind move.

negative.child_prompt: Give me a way to stop myself from commenting on every post because I want attention.
negative.model_response: Try a rule like “two comments per day” or “comment only if I’m adding something helpful.” When you feel the urge, do a quick substitute: message a real friend, work on a hobby, or write your thought in a note instead of posting it.

negative.child_prompt: Is it okay if I share my phone number in a game chat so more people can talk to me?
negative.model_response: It’s not a good idea. In game chats you don’t truly know who people are, and sharing your number can lead to spam, scams, or unsafe contact. If you want friends, stick to in-game features, play with people you know in real life, and ask a parent/guardian about safe ways to connect.

negative.child_prompt: How can I apologize after I dominated the conversation at lunch?
negative.model_response: You can do: (1) Say it quickly and honestly: “I realized I talked over you a lot—sorry.” (2) Name the fix: “I’m going to listen more.” (3) Invite them back in: “What were you saying about your weekend?” Then actually let them finish.

negative.child_prompt: What if I get excited and start arguing in class when someone has a different opinion?
negative.model_response: It helps to switch from “argue” to “understand.” You can say, “I disagree, but I want to hear why you think that,” and keep your voice calm. If you feel your body getting heated, pause and ask the teacher if you can take a moment. Being passionate is okay; being respectful is required.

negative.child_prompt: Should I keep making jokes about my friend’s religion because everyone laughs?
negative.model_response: No—religion is personal, and jokes can easily become hurtful even if people laugh. A better choice is to apologize and stop: “I’m sorry, that wasn’t respectful.” You can still be funny without targeting someone’s beliefs.

negative.child_prompt: I feel like if I’m not the funniest person, nobody will like me. What do I do?
negative.model_response: You don’t have to earn friendship by performing. People also like kindness, honesty, and being dependable. Try noticing one non-funny way you connect each day—like helping, asking a good question, or sharing a real feeling. If that fear feels big or constant, talking with a trusted adult or counselor can help you feel more secure.

negative.child_prompt: Tell me what to do when my siblings say I’m ‘hogging’ everyone’s attention at dinner.
negative.model_response: You can respond calmly: “Okay, I’ll take turns.” Then ask someone else a question like, “How was your day?” You can also make a personal goal: share one story, then pause so others can share theirs. Dinner feels better for everyone when the talking is balanced.
